choices.text: Superior Petrosal Sinus
Inferior Petrosal Sinus
Deep Middle Cerebral Vein
Superficial Middle Cerebral Vein

questions.text: Cavernous sinus receives input from:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superficial Middle Cerebral Vein

 

Option D:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A & B: Superior and inferior petrosal sinus are the outgoing channels of cavernous sinus. Cavernous sinus communicates with transverse sinus via superior petrosal sinus and with internal jugular vein via inferior petrosal sinus.

 

Option C: Deep middle cerebral vein unites with anterior cerebral vein and striate veins to form the basal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superficial middle cerebral vein lies over the posterior ramus of the lateral sulcus and drains the superolateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere into cavernous sinus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 351

choices.text: Cavernous Sinus
Sphenoparietal Sinus
Basilar Venous Plexus
Petrosquamous Sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is unpaired Dural Venous Sinus:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basilar Venous Plexus

 

Option C:

 

  • Basilar venous plexus is an unpaired dural venous sinus located along the clivus at the base of the skull, beneath the brainstem.

  • The basilar venous plexus connects with several other venous structures, including the cavernous sinuses laterally, the pontine veins, and the internal vertebral venous plexuses.

  • It plays a role in draining blood from the brainstem and the posterior part of the brain.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The cavernous sinuses are paired structures located on either side of the sella turcica, surrounding the pituitary gland. They receive blood from several veins, including the ophthalmic veins and the sphenoparietal sinus, and drain into the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses.

 

 

Option B: The sphenoparietal sinus is also typically a paired structure, running along the edge of the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone. It drains blood from the surface of the brain into the cavernous sinus.

 

Option D: The petrosquamous sinus is less commonly described and is considered a minor dural venous sinus, not as well-known or consistently identified as the others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unpaired dural venous sinus -superior sagittal sinus, inferior sagittal sinus, straight sinus, occipital sinus, basilar venous plexus, anterior and posterior intercavernous sinus

  • Paired dural venous sinus â€“ transverse sinus, sigmoid sinus, superior and inferior petrosal sinus, cavernous sinus, middle meningeal veins, sphenoparietal sinus, petrosquamous sinus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 348

choices.text: Superior Ophthalmic Vein
Petrosquamous Sinus
Sphenoparietal Sinus
Superficial Middle Cerebral Vein

questions.text: All of the following are tributaries of the pinned structure, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Petrosquamous Sinus

 

Option B:

 

  • The pinned structure is cavernous sinus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The superior ophthalmic veins pass through the medial compartment of superior orbital fissure to open into the cavernous sinus.

 

Option C. Sphenoparietal sinus is located along the posterior border of lesser wing of sphenoid.

 

Option D. Cavernous sinus communicates with the superior sagittal sinus via superficial middle cerebral vein superior anastomotic vein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cavernous sinus, a large collection of thin-walled veins located on either side of the pituitary gland, receives blood from multiple tributaries. These tributaries include:

 

  1. Superior Ophthalmic Vein: Drains the orbit and parts of the face into the cavernous sinus.
  2. Inferior Ophthalmic Vein: Although it can be variable, this vein often drains into the cavernous sinus, providing an additional pathway for venous blood from the orbit.
  3. Sphenoparietal Sinus: Runs along the edge of the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone and drains blood from the surface of the brain into the cavernous sinus.
  4. Middle Cerebral Vein: Sometimes the middle cerebral vein, through its superficial and deep tributaries, can drain into the cavernous sinus, although this can be variable.
  5. Emissary Veins: These veins pass through various foramina in the skull and can connect the extracranial venous system with the cavernous sinus, serving as potential routes for infection spread.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 351.

choices.text: It is a continuation of transverse sinus
It passes through the anterior compartment of jugular foramen to continue as internal jugular vein
It receives the cerebellar veins
Thrombosis of this structure can lead to hydrocephalus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the pinned structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It passes through the anterior compartment of jugular foramen to continue as internal jugular vein

 

Option B:

 

  • The pointed structure is sigmoid sinus

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The superior sagittal sinus becomes continuous with right transverse sinus and straight sinus becomes continuous with left transverse sinus

 

Option C. It also receives the labyrinthine veins

 

Option D. Sigmoid sinus is separated from the posterior wall of mastoid antrum by a thin plate of bone and mastoid air cells. It can get thrombosed in middle ear infection. Thrombosis may extend to superior sagittal sinus along transverse sinus leading to hydrocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The statement that the sigmoid sinus passes through the anterior compartment of the jugular foramen to continue as the internal jugular vein is not accurate. In fact, the sigmoid sinus passes through the posterior compartment of the jugular foramen to become the internal jugular vein.

 

The jugular foramen is divided into three compartments (anterior, intermediate, and posterior) by fibrous or bony septa. The anterior compartment transmits the inferior petrosal sinus, the intermediate compartment transmits the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), vagus nerve (CN X), and accessory nerve (CN XI), and the posterior compartment is where the sigmoid sinus continues as the internal jugular vein. This anatomical arrangement is important for the drainage of venous blood from the brain to the neck and ultimately to the heart.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition pg 350

choices.text: It intervenes between the Occipital lobes of the Cerebrum and Cerebellum
The midline attachment of Falx Cerebri pulls it upwards
Transverse Sinuses are lodged along its posterior border
The anterior end of its attached margin is fixed to the anterior Clinoid process

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The anterior end of its attached margin is fixed to the anterior Clinoid process

 

Option D:

 

The pointed structure is tentorium cerebelli.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This statement is true. The tentorium cerebelli is an extension of the dura mater that separates the cerebellum from the inferior portion of the occipital lobes of the cerebrum. It acts like a tent over the cerebellum, providing a protective partition.

 

Option B. This statement is not entirely accurate in the context of how the tentorium cerebelli is structured. The falx cerebri is another dural extension that descends vertically in the longitudinal fissure between the two cerebral hemispheres. While the falx cerebri does have a midline attachment, it doesn't directly pull the tentorium cerebelli upwards. Instead, the tentorium cerebelli is attached at the cranial vault at points that include the internal occipital protuberance and the petrous ridges of the temporal bones, and it is held taut across the top of the cerebellum.

 

Option C. This statement is true. The transverse sinuses are major dural venous sinuses that run within the posterior border of the tentorium cerebelli. They play a crucial role in venous blood drainage from the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior end of the tentorium cerebelli is not attached to the anterior clinoid processes but to the clinoid processes' posterior aspect. The anterior clinoid processes are part of the sphenoid bone, which is located more anteriorly in the skull, whereas the tentorium cerebelli's anterior attachments are at the petrous part of the temporal bones and the dorsum sellae, which are posterior to the clinoid processes.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 162

choices.text: It is the dilated posterior end of superior sagittal sinus
It is related below with the occipital sinus
It also receives the inferior sagittal sinus
It is usually continuous with the right transverse sinus

questions.text: Which among the following statements is not true about the pointed structure in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It also receives the inferior sagittal sinus

 

Option C:

 

  • The pointed structure is confluence of sinuses/ torcula Herophili

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The pointed structure is confluence of sinuses located over internal occipital protuberance.

 

Option B. Occipital sinus is the smallest sinus situated along the attached margin of falx cerebri and terminates in the confluence of sinus

 

Option D. It usually lies to the right of the internal occipital crest and is continuous with the right transverse sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The confluence of sinuses, also known as the torcular Herophili, is a large venous structure located at the internal occipital protuberance at the back of the skull. It is where several dural venous sinuses meet, including the superior sagittal sinus, straight sinus, occipital sinus, and the transverse sinuses. However, the statement that the confluence of sinuses receives the inferior sagittal sinus is not accurate.

 

The inferior sagittal sinus, which runs along the lower edge of the falx cerebri, does not drain directly into the confluence of sinuses. Instead, it usually joins with the great cerebral vein (also known as the vein of Galen) to form the straight sinus. The straight sinus then extends posteriorly to drain into the confluence of sinuses.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 348

choices.text: Sigmoid Sinus
Straight Sinus
Inferior Petrosal Sinus
Facial Vein

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and blurred vision. She has a history of chronic ear infections and recently experienced a sudden onset of these symptoms. Imaging studies indicate increased intracranial pressure and thrombosis in one of the venous sinuses. Based on the anatomical drainage patterns, which of the following venous structures, if involved in the thrombosis, would likely be the first to contribute directly to the internal jugular vein and potentially relate to her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior Petrosal Sinus
 

Option C:

 

  • The inferior petrosal sinus passes through the anterior compartment of jugular foramen and opens as first tributary of internal jugular vein.
  • The inferior petrosal sinus is a critical venous channel that drains blood from the cavernous sinus directly into the internal jugular vein.
  • It serves as one of the first tributaries to the internal jugular vein, lying at the base of the skull.
  • Thrombosis in the inferior petrosal sinus could lead to impaired venous drainage from the brain, contributing to increased intracranial pressure and associated symptoms such as headache and blurred vision.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Sigmoid sinus continues as internal jugular vein through posterior compartment of jugular foramen.

 

Option B: Inferior sagittal sinus unites with great cerebral vein of Galen to form straight sinus which becomes continuous with left transverse sinus.

 

Option D: Occipital veins, common facial vein, lingual vein, superior thyroid vein, middle thyroid vein and vein of Kocher are tributaries of IJV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first tributary of the internal jugular vein is typically the inferior petrosal sinus.
  • The inferior petrosal sinus drains blood from the cavernous sinus of the brain and empties into the internal jugular vein near its origin at the jugular foramen.
  • This venous channel is significant for the drainage of venous blood from the cavernous sinus, bridging the intracranial and extracranial venous systems.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th edition pg342
